newsitem.title: USA: FEATURE - Ice-T tries some satire on new album.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Ice-T tries some satire on new album.

text.p: Ice-T has spent his life raising other people's hackles, whether in his younger days as a jewel thief or later as a pioneering "gangsta" rapper.
He upped the ante a few years ago when he formed a hard rock band called Body Count and wrote a song about police brutality called "Cop Killer," which enraged the American political establishment.

But, ever-paranoid about going over old ground and risking "corniness," he wants to be seen as more than a menace to society. He showcases his skills as a comedian and satirist on Body Count's third album, which has just hit the streets.

Bob Newhart or Jeff Foxworthy need not worry about the new competition. Titled "Violent Demise: The Last Days," the album celebrates strippers, pokes fun at music journalists, honours Dr. Jack Kevorkian and even features a searing indictment of O.J. Simpson.

Such dark humour might surprise fans of the last Body Count album, "Born Dead," which dealt with drive-by shootings, racism and grisly deaths. But Ice-T says his songs reflect what is happening around him at any given time. While "Born Dead" came out in 1994 with memories of the Los Angeles riots still fresh in his mind, life has moved on.

"This year, we were back in L.A. We were dealing with rich, white kids going to Palm Springs, partying, getting drunk," he told Reuters at his home high up in the Hollywood Hills. "You can't expect a kid out here that's in Brentwood riding about in his father's BMW to feel 'Born Dead,' y'know?"
PLEAS TO 'TELL IT LIKE IT IS'

His spacious house with its swimming pool, black leather couches and 60-inch TV screen overlooks the vast Los Angeles urban sprawl and Ice-T never forgets the friends he left behind in the housing projects. They bombard him with pleas to "tell it like it is," so the album has its more sombre moments such as "Truth or Death" and "Root of All Evil."

The album's notes acknowledge the contributions of "all vampires, serial killers, psychopaths, career criminals, pimps, hos, kidnappers and drug dealers" who have provided Ice-T with inspiration. "If this world was only full of angels, there would be no Ice-T," he explained. "As they kill and murder and rape and rob, I'll always have material."

Ice-T, in his late 30s, certainly makes no claim to being an angel. Born Tracy Marrow, he was orphaned at an early age and ended up on the mean streets of South-Central Los Angeles as a member of the Crips gang. He began stealing jewelry and was frequently jailed before his first rap album in 1987.
Now he says he finds humour in the worst things. "I'm just a fool. That's how I am. Everything is a joke to me. My buddies say I do anything for a laugh."

The Simpson saga, in which the former football star was acquitted of double murder in a criminal trial, then was found liable in a civil trial, seemed ridiculous to Ice-T. He believed Simpson to be guilty and wrote "I Used To Love Her," about the whole affair.
O.J. SIMPSON CASE 'IS SO STUPID'

"It could be considered wrong to make a joke about it, but it's so stupid, it's out there," he said. "I tend to sometimes talk about things in its humorous form to make you say, 'Damn, that is kind of stupid.'"

The album begins with a whining music journalist getting beaten up by Ice-T because he does not think Body Count rocks hard enough. A few tracks later is "Strippers," whose X-rated video runs on a Playboy cable channel.

Towards the end is "Dr. K," a song about the celebrated right-to-die advocate written by Body Count lead guitarist Ernie C. The song's message is that if you think life could not be worse "call the doc up, he'll pick you up in a hearse."
The death motif is fitting for Body Count, which Ice-T formed as a side project in 1989 with Ernie C. and some old friends from South-Central.

The band released its self-titled debut album in 1992 and made headlines a few months later when a police group picked up on the "Cop Killer" track and turned it into an election-year issue involving everyone from then-President George Bush to free-speech advocates.

The album flew out of stores amid the ensuing publicity before the group's label, Warner Bros., deleted the track from further pressings with Ice-T's approval. They split by mutual agreement soon after and the band signed with Virgin Records.

"I don't have a problem with the police at all," he says now. "It was a record about a guy who lost it because the brutal police was (messing) with him. I didn't know this cat I invented would become a hero."
